STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
December 2, 2021
Victoria Schultz
Catholic Charities of Shiawassee and Genesee Co
901 Chippewa Street
Flint, MI 48503
RE: License #: CB250201015
Catholic Charities of Shiawassee and Genesee Co.
901 Chippewa Street
Flint, MI 48503
Dear Ms. Schultz:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 12/1/2021.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and Modified
Settlement Agreement (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective action plan is required.
It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
Pinkey Brown, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3012
Enclosure
Deborah Pettway
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 12 months
before placement or a new physical examination shall be
completed within 30 calendar days after placement.
One out of eight foster children’s records reviewed one did not
have a physical examination.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and
at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
One out of eight foster children’s records reviewed one child
updated service plan was one day late.
One out of eight foster children’s records reviewed one child
was missing the updated service plan for 10/29/20 – 1/26/21.
REPEAT CITATION FROM 10/19/2020 RENEWAL
INSPECTION
4

R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(1) There shall be a mutually agreed upon contract between
the youth and the agency specifying all of the following:
(a) The responsibilities of the agency and the youth.
One out of one independent living case record reviewed did not
have a mutually agreed upon contract between the youth and
social service worker.
R400.12607 Agency recommendation
(4) An agency shall provide the applicants for adoption
with a signed and dated copy of the evaluation and
recommendation upon its completion.
Three of three adoptive applicant evaluations reviewed,
three did not have documentation that they received a copy
of the agency’s recommendation.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
ISEP 4.22 MISACWIS (Commitment 22)
DHHS will maintain an operational statewide automated
Child welfare information system (“MiSACWIS”) which will
be the primary tracking system and satisfy federal
reporting requirements.
In several of six open foster child records, various records did
not show consistent uploads of all signed and timely
documentation such as parent agency treatment plans, updated
medical passports, USP’s, FTM’s, and adoptive child contract.
5

ISEP 6.30 Supervisory oversight (Commitment 66)
Supervisors shall meet at least monthly with each assigned
worker to review the status and progress of each case on
the worker’s caseload. Supervisors shall review and
approve each service plan. The plan can be approved only
after the supervisor has a face-to-face meeting with the
worker, which can be the monthly meeting.
Three out of eight foster care records reviewed, three did not have
supervision between the worker and supervisor documented
monthly/prior to signing a USP.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
DHHS POLICY Family Team Meeting
FOM 722-06B
Family Team Meeting Type Time Frame
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
Three out of six foster care records reviewed did not contain an
FTM for the reporting period.
Child One was missing a FTM for the reporting period 4/24/21 -
7/21/21.
Child Two was missing a FTM for the reporting period 5/15/21 -
8/5/21.
Child Three was missing a FTM for the reporting period 1/1/21 -
4/15/21. The FTM was completed after the report date on
4/24/21.
REPEAT CITATION FROM 10/19/20 RENEWAL INSPECTION
DHHS Policy Required Participation in Development - Foster Parent /
FOM 722-08C Caregiver and Birth Parent
Page 2
The foster parent/caregiver must be included in the PATP
process. The foster parent/caregiver signature is required
and indicates that the foster parent/caregiver
6

acknowledges and agrees to the activities required to meet
the needs of the child in their care.
Signatures must be documented within 30 days.
Four out of six foster care records reviewed did not have
documentation of a PATP signed by the caregiver.
Child One did not have a signed PATP for the bio-parent for
reporting period 12/9/20 -3/8/21 & 6/7/21 – 9/3/21.
Child Two did not have a signed PATP for the reporting period
6/22/21 – 9/17/21.
Child Three did not have a signed PATP for the bio-parent for
reporting period 4/24/21 – 7/21/21.
Child Four did not have a signed PATP for reporting period
11/25/20 – 2/22/21, 2/23/21 – 5/14/21 and 5/15/21 – 8/6/20.
REPEAT CITATION FROM 10/19/20 RENEWAL INSPECTION
DHHS Policy Medical Passport
FOM 801 – page
14-15
All medical information required by policy and/or law must
be provided to the foster parent. This includes copies of
the medical and dental examinations (if available) and the
information required in the medical passport. For children
first entering foster care, the initial medical passport must
be provided to the caregivers within two weeks of the
child's placement date. The actual date the caregivers
receive the medical passport must be documented in
MiSACWIS. All medical information within the medical
passport must be current and updated at least quarterly to
reflect the child's current and complete health information.
Placement agency foster care (PAFC) providers must
provide a copy of the medical passport to MDHHS
monitoring staff as it is updated but no less often than
annually. Each foster care worker who transfers a child's
medical passport to another foster care worker must sign
and date the medical passport verifying that s/he has
sought and obtained the necessary information under law
and MDHHS policy. An updated medical passport is
provided to: Legal parents if the child is a temporary court
ward. All medical and mental health professionals to whom
the child is referred and accepted for treatment.
-The child’s foster care provider at or prior to each
placement. This includes foster homes, relative
placements and residential facilities.
7

-Legal parents quarterly and at reunification if the child
is a temporary court ward.
-All medical and mental health professionals to whom
the child is referred and accepted for treatment
Four out of six foster care records reviewed did not have
documentation of a medical passport or an updated passport.
Child One did not have a medical passport in the case records.
Child Two did not have an updated medical passport.
Child Three did not have an updated medical passport.
Child Four did not have an updated medical passport.
FOM 722-09C FOSTER CARE ACTION SUMMARY REQUIREMENTS
Page 1-2
The Foster Care/Juvenile Justice (FC/JJ) Action Summary,
DHHS-69 (RFF 69), is used whenever there is “action” on a
case. The foster care action summary is generated from
SWSS FAJ. The DHHS worker must complete the DHHS-69,
Action Summary (RFF 69) in SWSS. Child placing agencies
will continue to use the DHHS-69, Action Summary
template. This form also serves as notice to the courts of
changes in placements, parent's living situation and the FC
worker/agency, as identifying information is indicated. The
FC/JJ action summary meets licensing requirements for
replacement documentation (See FOM 722-03) and in most
cases, agency transfer and case closing summary (see
below). The FC/JJ action summary must also be used for
foster care transfer to adoption.
Two out of four closed foster care case records reviewed did not
Have the required DHHS -69 Closing Action Summary
completed.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was not offered technical assistance.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation.
8

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were three substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
There were three incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period. Thea agency appropriately cited the foster parents and developed
corrective action plans to include additional training and review of policies and
procedures.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. A corrective action plan was submitted for
the 10/19/2020 renewal inspection report. It appropriately addressed the following
as no repeat citations are noted: placement, change of placement, foster parent
information, adoptive family evaluation, training requirements and assessment and
service plans. Repeat citations include the following: development of service plans,
required participation in development and family team meeting.
VII. DCWL FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concern.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that Catholic Charities of
Shiawassee and Genesee County continue on a regular license.
9

12/02/2021
________________________________________
Pinkey Brown Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
December 3, 2021

Linda Tansil Date
Area Manager
